facts.text: Petition No. 128 of 1958 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution by the 51st Dai-ul-Mutlaq challenging the constitutionality of the Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 128 of 1958. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights. M. Munshi, R. J. Joshi, G.K. Munshi, T.S.N. Diwanji, J.B. Dadachanji, S.N. Andley, Rameshwar Nath and P. L. Vohra, for the petitioner.

facts.text: Petitioner is the 51st Dai-ul-Mutlaq and head of the Dawoodi Bohra Community.

anchor.surface_text: the petitioner, who is the 51st Dai-ul-Mutlaq and head of the Dawoodi Bohra Community challenges the companystitutionality of the Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act, 1949  Bombay Act XLII of 1949   hereinafter referred to as the Act  on the ground that the provisions of the Act infringe Arts. 25 and 26 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Dawoodi Bohra Community consists of Muslims of the Shia sect, Ismailis.

anchor.surface_text: The Dawoodi Bohra Community companysist of Muslims of the Shia sect, holding in companymon with all members of that sect the belief that there is one God, that Mohammed is His Prophet to whom He revealed the Holy Koran that Ali, the son-in-law of Mohammed, was the Wasi  executor  of the Prophet, and that the said Ali succeeded the Prophet by Nas-e-Jali.

facts.text: The 21st Imam went into seclusion due to persecution.

anchor.surface_text: The Dawoodi Bohras belong to the former sect, and believe that owing to persecution Imam Type  the 21st Imam  went into seclusion and that an Iman from his line appear, it being their belief that an Iman always exists although at times he may be invisible to his believers, while in seclusion

facts.text: Petitioner as Dai-ul-Mutlaq has power of excommunication exercised according to usage and tenets, not absolute.

anchor.surface_text: He has also the power of excommunication. This power of excommunication is number an absolute, arbitrary and untrammelled power, but has to be exercised according to the usage and tenets of the companymunity. Save in exceptional circumstances, expulsion from the companymunity can be effected only at a meeting of the Jamat, after the person companycerned has given due warning of the fault companyplained of and an opportunity of mending, and after a public statement of the grounds of expulsion.

facts.text: Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act, 1949 came into force on November 1, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay Legislature enacted the Act, which came into force on November 1, 1949.

facts.text: Tayebhai Moosaji Koicha instituted suit No. 1262 of 1949 in Bombay High Court against petitioner for declaration that excommunication orders prior to the Act were void.

anchor.surface_text: One Tayebhai Moosaji Koicha  Mandivala  instituted a suit, being suit No. 1262 of 1949, in the High Court of Judicature at Bombay, praying inter alia, for a declaration that certain orders of excommunication passed by the petitioner against him prior to the enactment of the Act were void and illegal and of numbereffect, and that the plaintiff companytinued to remain a member of the Dawoodi Bohra companymunity.

facts.text: J.C. Shah J. held on February 21, 1952 that the Act is not inconsistent with Art. 26 and not ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: The said suit was heard by J.C. Shah, J., who, by his judgment dated February 21, 1952, held that the Act was number inconsistent with Art. 26 of the Constitution, and was number ultra vires the Legislature of the Province of Bombay.

facts.text: Division Bench (Chagla CJ and Bhagwati J) upheld single judge on August 26, 1952 on different grounds.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner, being dissatisfied with the judgment of the learned Judge, preferred an appeal that came up for hearing before the Court of Appeal, companyposed of Chagla, C. J., and Bhagwati J. By its judgment dated August 26, 1952, the Court of Appeal upheld the judgment of the learned single Judge, though on different grounds.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 99 of 1954 to Supreme Court dismissed on November 27, 1957 as cause of action did not survive plaintiff's death.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner obtained leave from the High Court to appeal to this Court, and ultimately filed the appeal, being Civil Appeal No. 99 of 1954. During the pendency of the appeal, the plaintiff-respondent aforesaid died and an application made on behalf of his heirs for being brought on the record was number granted by the High Court of Bombay. This Court dismissed the said appeal on the ground that the plaintiff having died, the cause of action did number survive. The Order of this Court dismissing the appeal as number maintainable is dated November 27, 1957.

facts.text: Petitioner's attorneys letter dated July 18, 1958 to respondent requesting to desist from enforcing the Act.

anchor.surface_text: By the petitioners attorneys letter, annexure B to the petition, dated July 18, 1958, the petitioner pointed out to the respondent the unconstitutionality of the Act and requested the latter to desist from enforcing the provisions of the Act against the petitioner or against the Dawoodi Bohra companymunity.

facts.text: Respondent states petitioner has no cause of action as no proceedings to excommunicate taken.

anchor.surface_text: The answer of the State of Bombay, the sole respondent, is companytained in the affidavit sworn to by Shri V.N. Kalghatgi, Assistant Secretary to the Government of Bombay, Home Department, to the effect that the petitioner number having taken any proceedings to excommunicate any member of the companymunity had numbercause of action or right to institute the proceedings under Art. 32 of the Constitution

facts.text: Kurbanhusain Sanchawala applied in April 1961 to intervene or be added as party.

anchor.surface_text: At a very late stage of the pendency of the proceedings in this Court, in April 1961, one Kurbanhusein Sanchawala of Bombay, made an application either for being added as a party to the Writ Petition or, alternatively, for being granted leave to intervene in the proceedings.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on January 9, 1962 by Sinha CJ, Das Gupta J for Sarkar, Das Gupta, Mudholkar JJ, separate by Ayyangar J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. January 9-Sinha. C.J., delivered his own Judgment. The Judgment of Sarkar, Das Gupta and Mudholkar, JJ., was delivered by Das Gupta, J. Ayyangar J. delivered a separate Judgment.

facts.text: Court assumes petitioner has power to excommunicate for the purpose of this case.

anchor.surface_text: As we are number here directly companycerned with the question whether or number the petitioner as the head of the religious companymunity had the power to excommunicate, we did number hear Mr. Shroff at any length with reference to that question. We shall proceed to determine the companytroversy in this case on the assumption that the petitioner had that power.

facts.text: Privy Council in Hasan Ali v. Mansoor Ali held Dai has power to excommunicate but not absolute, dated December 1, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the Privy Council was given on December 1, 1947. Within two years of that judgment the impugned Act was passed... In that case, their Lordships did number uphold the claim of the Dai-ul-Mutlaq that he had unrestricted power of excommunication, though they found that he companyld be regarded as Dai-ul-Mutlaq. As regards the power to excommunicate, it was held that though the power was there, it was number absolute, arbitrary and untrammelled

facts.text: Effect of valid excommunication is exclusion from religious rights in places under trusteeship of Dai.

anchor.surface_text: The result of excommunication properly and legally effected involves exclusion from the exercise of religious rights in places under the trusteeship of the Dai-ul-Mustlaq.

facts.text: Act declares excommunication invalid and penalizes acts in furtherance thereof.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 3, excommunication of a member of a companymunity has been declared to be invalid and of numbereffect, numberwithstanding any law, custom or usage to the companytrary. Any act of excommunication, or any act in furtherance of excommunication, of any member of a companymunity has been made a penal offence liable to a punishment, on companyviction, of fine which may extend to one thousand rupees.

facts.text: Petitioner claims excommunication is integral part of religion protected by Arts. 25 and 26.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner claims that as the head of the Dawoodi Bohra companymunity and as Dai-ul-Mutlaq, he has the right and power, in a proper case and subject to the companyditions of legal exercise of that power, to excommunicate a member of the Dawoodi Bohra companymunity, and this power of excommunication is an integral part of the religious faith and belief of the Dawoodi Bohra companymunity.

facts.text: Respondent denies that right to excommunicate is essential part of religion.

anchor.surface_text: that it was denied that the right to excommunicate springs from or has its foundation in religion and religious doctrines, tenets and faith of the Dawoodi Bohra companymunity that, at any rate, it was denied that the right to excommunicate was an essential part of the religion of the companymunity that, alternatively, assuming that it was part of a religious practice, it runs companynter to public order, morality and health.

facts.text: Das Gupta J holds Act violates Art. 26(b), petition succeeds.

anchor.surface_text: Our companyclusion is that the Act is void being in violation of Art. 26 of the Constitution. The companytrary view taken by the Bombay High Court in Taher Saifuddin v. Tyebbhai Moosaji  1  is number companyrect. We would, therefore, allow the petition, declare the Act to be void

facts.text: Sinha CJ holds Act constitutional, petition fails.

anchor.surface_text: In my opinion, it has number been established that the Act has been passed by a legislature which was number companypetent to legislate on the subject, or that it infringes any of the provisions of the Constitution. This petition must, therefore, fail.

issues.text: Whether the provisions of the Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act, 1949 infringe Articles 25 and 26 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: the provisions of the Act infringe Arts. 25 and 26 of the Constitution. The sole respondent in this case is the State of Bombay. The petition is founded on the following allegations. The Dawoodi Bohra Community consist of Muslims of the Shia sect, holding in common with all members of that sect the belief that there is one God, that Mohammed is His Prophet to whom He revealed the Holy Koran that Ali, the son-in-law of Mohammed, was the Wasi (executor) of the Prophet, and that the said Ali succeeded the Prophet by Nas-e-Jali.

issues.text: Whether the Bombay Legislature was competent to enact the Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act, 1949

anchor.surface_text: the legislative competence of the Bombay Legislature to enact the Act has not been seriously challenged before us

issues.text: Whether the provisions of the Act, insofar as they have rendered invalid the practice of excommunication, are unconstitutional as infringing Art. 26(b)

anchor.surface_text: We are only directly concerned with the questions whether the provisions of the Act, insofar as they have rendered invalid the practice of excommunication, are unconstitutional as infringing Art. 26 b , and enacted by a legislature which was not competent to do so, as contended on behalf of the petitioner. We will, therefore, confine our attention to those questions. Keeping in view the limited scope of the controversy, we have first to determine the ambit and effect of the impugned Act.

issues.text: Whether the Act was enacted by a legislature which was not competent to do so

anchor.surface_text: and enacted by a legislature which was not competent to do so, as contended on behalf of the petitioner. We will, therefore, confine our attention to those questions. Keeping in view the limited scope of the controversy, we have first to determine the ambit and effect of the impugned Act. The Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act (Bombay Act XLII of 1949) is an Act to prohibit excommunication in the province of Bombay.

issues.text: Has the impugned Act interfered with a right freely to practise religion

anchor.surface_text: Before however we can give a proper answer to the two questions raised, viz., (i) Has the impugned Act interfered with a right freely to practise religion and (ii) Has it interfered with the right of the Dawoodi Bohra Community to manage its own affairs in matters of religion it is necessary to examine first the place of excommunication in the life of a religious community.

issues.text: Has it interfered with the right of the Dawoodi Bohra Community to manage its own affairs in matters of religion

anchor.surface_text: (ii) Has it interfered with the right of the Dawoodi Bohra Community to manage its own affairs in matters of religion it is necessary to examine first the place of excommunication in the life of a religious community. Much valuable information about this is furnished by an article in the Encyclopaedia of the Social Sciences from the pen of Prof. Hazeltine.

issues.text: Whether the Act is void in so far as it is repugnant to the guaranteed rights under Arts. 25 and 26 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: It now remains to consider the main point in controversy, which was, as a matter of fact, the only point urged in support of the petition, namely, that the Act is void in so far as it is repugnant to the guaranteed rights under Arts. 25 and 26 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Was the Act within the legislative competence of the Legislature of the Province of Bombay? Whether after the coming into force of the Constitution, the Act was invalid in view of Arts. 25 and 26 of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: Two questions, by way of preliminary issues, with which we are immediately concerned in the present proceedings, were raised before the learned Judge of the Bombay High Court, namely Was the Act within the legislative competence of the Legislature of the Province of Bombay ? Whether after the coming into force of the Constitution, the Act was invalid in view of Arts. 25 and 26 of the Constitution?

holdings.text: We shall proceed to determine the controversy in this case on the assumption that the petitioner had that power.

anchor.surface_text: As we are not here directly concerned with the question whether or not the petitioner as the head of the religious community had the power to excommunicate, we did not hear Mr. Shroff at any length with reference to that question. We shall proceed to determine the controversy in this case on the assumption that the petitioner had that power.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court assumes power exists to focus on constitutionality, avoiding dispute settled by Privy Council.

holdings.text: The legislative competence of the Bombay Legislature to enact the Act has not been seriously challenged before us.

anchor.surface_text: the legislative competence of the Bombay Legislature to enact the Act has not been seriously challenged before us

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pith and substance within Entries 1 & 2 List III Concurrent List of 1935 Act; not pressed by petitioner.

holdings.text: The Bombay Legislature was competent to enact the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In my opinion, therefore, the enactment, in pith and substance, would come within Entries 1 & 2 of List III of the Concurrent Legislative List of the Constitution Act of 1935.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pith and substance analysis places Act under social reform and criminal law entries.

holdings.text: It is not disputed that the petitioner is the head of the Dawoodi Bohra community or that the Dawoodi Bohra community is a religious denomination within the meaning of Art. 26 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We are only directly concerned with the questions whether the provisions of the Act, insofar as they have rendered invalid the practice of excommunication, are unconstitutional as infringing Art. 26 b , and enacted by a legislature which was not competent to do so, as contended on behalf of the petitioner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepted by parties; Dawoodi Bohras qualify as religious denomination under Art. 26.

holdings.text: Our conclusion is that the Act is void being in violation of Art. 26 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Our conclusion is that the Act is void being in violation of Art. 26 of the Constitution. The contrary view taken by the Bombay High Court in Taher Saifuddin v. Tyebbhai Moosaji  1  is not correct. We would, therefore, allow the petition, declare the Act to be void

holdings.reasoning_summary: Excommunication on religious grounds is matter of religion; Act interferes with management of religious affairs under Art. 26(b); not saved by Art. 25(2).

holdings.text: Where an excommunication is itself based on religious grounds... excommunication cannot but be held to be for the purpose of maintaining the strength of the religion... the exercise of this power of excommunication on religious grounds forms part of the management by the community... of its own affairs in matters of religion.

anchor.surface_text: Before however we can give a proper answer to the two questions raised, viz., (i) Has the impugned Act interfered with a right freely to practise religion and (ii) Has it interfered with the right of the Dawoodi Bohra Community to manage its own affairs in matters of religion it is necessary to examine first the place of excommunication in the life of a religious community.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Excommunication for heresy/apostasy/breach of essential practices is religious matter; denomination autonomy per Shirur Mutt.

holdings.text: The barring of excommunication on religious grounds pure and simple, cannot however be considered to promote social welfare and reform.

anchor.surface_text: The mere fact that certain civil rights which might be lost by members of the Dawoodi Bohra community as a result of excommunication even though made on religious grounds

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 25(2)(b) saving inapplicable to religious excommunication; distinguishes secular from religious grounds.

holdings.text: The impugned Act cannot be regarded as a law regulating or restricting any economic, financial, political or other secular activity.

anchor.surface_text: Quite clearly, the impugned Act cannot be regarded as a law regulating or restricting any economic, financial, political or other secular activity which may be associated with religious practice

holdings.reasoning_summary: Excommunication not secular activity under Art. 25(2)(a).

holdings.text: In my opinion, it has not been established that the Act has been passed by a legislature which was not competent to legislate on the subject, or that it infringes any of the provisions of the Constitution. This petition must, therefore, fail.

anchor.surface_text: In my opinion, it has not been established that the Act has been passed by a legislature which was not competent to legislate on the subject, or that it infringes any of the provisions of the Constitution. This petition must, therefore, fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dissent: excommunication concerns civil rights, not purely religious; saved by Art. 25(2)(b) social reform; upholds Act.

anchor.surface_text: Those provisions have, therefore, to be so construed as to create no conflict between them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction per Venkataramana Devaru; but Act not within 25(2)(b).

anchor.surface_text: excommunicate, in spite of the decision of their Lordships of the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in Hasan Ali v. Mansoor Ali 1 . He also supported the provisions of the impugned Act on the ground that they were in furtherance of public order. As we are not here directly concerned with the question whether or not the petitioner as the head of the religious community had the power to excommunicate, we did not hear Mr. Shroff at any length with reference to that question.

precedents.cited_proposition: Dai-ul-Mutlaq has power to excommunicate members of the Dawoodi Bohra community
precedents.cited_holding: the Dai-ul-Mutlaq has the power of excommunication subject to conditions like usage and tenets, not absolute

precedents.citation: The Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt 1

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, reliance was placed on the decision of this Court in The Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt 1 , which, it is contended, has laid down that the guarantee under the Constitution not only protects the freedom of opinion, but also acts done in pursuance of such religious opinion, and that it is the denomination itself which has a right to determine what are essential parts of its religion, as protected by the provisions of Arts. 25 and 26 of the Constitution.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt
precedents.cited_proposition: guarantee under Constitution protects acts done in pursuance of religious opinion; denomination determines essential parts of religion

anchor.surface_text: the more directly in point is the litigation which was concluded by the judgment of their Lordships of the Judicial Committee of the privy Council in the case of Hasanali v. Mansoorali 1 . In that case, the powers of the Dai-ul-Mutlaq to excommunicate were directly in controversy. The petitioner was the first defendant in that action, which had been commenced in October, 1925, and was decided by the judgment of the Subordinate Judge of Burhanpur, dated January 2, 1931.

precedents.cited_proposition: powers of Dai-ul-Mutlaq to excommunicate; conditions for valid exercise; effect is exclusion from religious rights in community properties
precedents.cited_holding: Dai has power to excommunicate but not absolute; must follow procedure; effect excludes from religious rights in trusteeship places

precedents.citation: Advocate General ex relation Dave Muhammad v. Muhammad v. Husen Huseni 1

anchor.surface_text: The first reported case in relation to some aspects of Shia Imami Ismailis is that of the Advocate General ex relation Dave Muhammad v. Muhammad v. Husen Huseni 1 . That was a suit commenced before the coming into existence of the Bombay High Court, on the Equity Side of the late Supreme Court, instituted by an information and bill, filed by the relators and plaintiffs, representing a minority of the Khoja community, against the defendants representing the majority of that community.

precedents.case_name: Advocate General ex relation Dave Muhammad v. Muhammad v. Husen Huseni
precedents.cited_proposition: historical context of Khoja community; Aga Khan as spiritual head determines membership on religious grounds
precedents.cited_holding: no public property for whole Khoja community; Aga Khan entitled to determine members on religious grounds

precedents.citation: the Advocate General of Bombay v. Yusufalli Ebrahim 1

anchor.surface_text: The next reported case which was brought to our notice is the case of the Advocate General of Bombay v. Yusufalli Ebrahim 1 . That was a case directly in relation to the Dawoodi Bohra community, with which we are concerned in this case. In that case, there was a dispute as regards a mosque and a tomb, and was heard by Marten J., on the Original side in 1921.

precedents.case_name: Advocate General of Bombay v. Yusufalli Ebrahim
precedents.cited_proposition: history and position of Dai-ul-Mutlaq in Dawoodi Bohra community

precedents.citation: The Durgah Committee, Ajmer v. Syed Hussain Ali 1

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, the following observations of this Court in The Durgah Committee, Ajmer v. Syed Hussain Ali 1 which were made with reference to the earlier decisions of this Court in The Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt 2 and in Sri Venkataramana Devaru v. The State of Mysore 3 , that matters of religion in Art. 26 b include even practices which are regarded by the community as part of its religion, may be noted

precedents.case_name: Durgah Committee, Ajmer v. Syed Hussain Ali
precedents.cited_proposition: matters of religion include practices regarded by community as essential and integral part; caution against secular practices clothed as religious
precedents.cited_holding: protection under Art. 26 confined to essential and integral religious practices

precedents.citation: Sri Venkataramana Devaru v. The State of Mysore 1

anchor.surface_text: This very argument was advanced in the case of Shri Venkataramana Devaru v. The State of Mysore 1 . At page 916 this argument has been specifically dealt with and negatived. This Court observed as follows The answer to this contention is that it is impossible to read any such limitation into the language of Art.25 2 b . It applies in terms to all religious institutions of a public character without qualification or reserve.

precedents.case_name: Sri Venkataramana Devaru v. State of Mysore
precedents.cited_proposition: Art. 26(b) subject to Art. 25(2)(b); denominational temples within Art. 25(2)(b)

precedents.citation: Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments Madras v. Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Matt 1

anchor.surface_text: The content of Arts. 25 and 26 of the Constitution came up for consideration before this Court in the Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments Madras v. Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Matt 1 Mahant Jagannath Ramanuj Das v. The State of Orissa 2 Sri Venkatamana Devaru v. The State of Mysore 3 Durgah Committee, Ajmer Syed Hussain Ali 4 and several other cases and the main principles underlying these provisions have by these decisions been placed beyond controversy.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments Madras v. Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Matt
precedents.cited_proposition: protection extends to acts in pursuance of religion; essential parts decided by courts with reference to doctrines

anchor.surface_text: The contrary view taken by the Bombay High Court in Taher Saifuddin v. Tyebbhai Moosaji 1 is not correct. We would, therefore, allow the petition, declare the Act to be void and direct the issue of a writ in the nature of mandamus on the respondent, the State of Bombay, not to enforce the provisions of the Act. The petitioner will get his costs.

Our conclusion is that the Act is void being in violation of Art. 26 of the Constitution. The contrary view taken by the Bombay High Court in Taher Saifuddin v. Tyebbhai Moosaji 1 is not correct. We would, therefore, allow the petition, declare the Act to be void and direct the issue of a writ in the nature of mandamus on the respondent, the State of Bombay, not to enforce the provisions of the Act. The petitioner will get his costs.

outcome.relief_summary: Petition allowed; Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act, 1949 declared void; writ in the nature of mandamus issued directing State of Bombay not to enforce the Act
directions: issue of a writ in the nature of mandamus on the respondent, the State of Bombay, not to enforce the provisions of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The mere fact that certain civil rights which might be lost by members of the Dawoodi Bohra community as a result of excommunication even though made on religious grounds

Our conclusion is that the Act is void being in violation of Art. 26 of the Constitution. The contrary view taken by the Bombay High Court in Taher Saifuddin v. Tyebbhai Moosaji 1 is not correct. We would, therefore, allow the petition, declare the Act to be void and direct the issue of a writ in the nature of mandamus on the respondent, the State of Bombay, not to enforce the provisions of the Act. The petitioner will get his costs.
